trigger_event: In the middle of citywide chaos after the 'data strike,' Directorate officials demand emergency approval to crack down on neighborhood assemblies and all citizen-run data networks, hoping to restore central control.
dilemma: Nikola must choose whether to authorize a full security crackdown on these emerging assemblies and networks—restoring Council power but crushing civic momentum—or to quietly block the order, letting citizens organize themselves even if it means risking disorder and exclusion. Each path points the city in a wholly different direction.
reason: Nikola knows both choices are irreversible: a crackdown could end the new trust among citizens, while allowing autonomy risks chaos, shortages, and blame. His authority makes his decision final, and both loyalty and compassion tug at him.
choice_a: Quietly blocks the Directorate’s crackdown order, allowing neighborhood assemblies and citizen-run networks to take charge of local services.
belief_a: Trust in the people grows only when they are free to act without fear.
Stability is rebuilt from mutual aid, not imposed force.
Genuine order comes from open deliberation, not silent authority.
choice_b: Authorizes the Directorate’s crackdown order, setting in motion targeted operations to dismantle all unauthorized assemblies and seize control over citizen-managed networks.
belief_b: Order can’t survive without strong, central direction.
Restoring authority protects the vulnerable, even if it’s harsh.
